commit_message:
Build selinux-permissive test images

With selinux enabled, the dib-built fedora image needs to do a full
relabel on boot, which is so slow in the gate environment that tests
are timing out.

This change makes wrapper elements for all the test distros which
allows for adding extra per-distro elements to the image like
selinux-permissive.

This change also goes back to image file names which have no timestamp.
This is because the publishing method is going to be to swift instead
of tarballs.o.o, and swift supports atomic uploads.

Change-Id: I797588a90f2aea2f60042739f35bd43b8b0c284c

commit_message:
Add default scheme key to node['openstack']['endpoints']

This allows the scheme to be specified in one place for all
services in the same way that bind-host can.
Also fix nit with bare-metal bind missing default.

Change-Id: I38b9cc15649db6c653ba9c5fc5b631f015c8b4dd

commit_message:
Security tests for Container resources

These tests will attempt CRUD operations on Container resources, both
with and without (dummy) project ids, and always without valid
tokens. They should all return HTTP 401s.

Change-Id: I582d29f7eab16e8bcfb17c1d1d66241df83edbd3

added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2014 Rackspace, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or # implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. from testtools import testcase from barbican.tests import utils from functionaltests.api import base from functionaltests.api.v1.behaviors import container_behaviors from functionaltests.api.v1.behaviors import secret_behaviors from functionaltests.api.v1.models import container_models from functionaltests.api.v1.models import secret_models create_secret_defaults_data = { "name": "AES key", "expiration": "2018-02-28T19:14:44.180394", "algorithm": "aes", "bit_length": 256, "mode": "cbc", "payload": "gF6+lLoF3ohA9aPRpt+6bQ==", "payload_content_type": "application/octet-stream", "payload_content_encoding": "base64", } create_container_defaults_data = { "name": "containername", "type": "generic", "secret_refs": [ { "name": "secret1", }, { "name": "secret2", }, { "name": "secret3" } ] } create_container_rsa_data = { "name": "rsacontainer", "type": "rsa", "secret_refs": [ { "name": "public_key", }, { "name": "private_key", }, { "name": "private_key_passphrase" } ] } create_container_empty_data = { "name": None, "type": "generic", "secret_refs": [] } dummy_project_id = 'dummy123' dummy_container_ref = 'containers/dummy123-3416-4b53-8875-e6af3e0af8c3' @utils.parameterized_test_case class ContainersTestCase(base.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(ContainersTestCase, self).setUp() self.secret_behaviors = secret_behaviors.SecretBehaviors(self.client) self.behaviors = container_behaviors.ContainerBehaviors( self.client ) # Set up three secrets secret_ref_1 = self._create_a_secret() secret_ref_2 = self._create_a_secret() secret_ref_3 = self._create_a_secret() create_container_defaults_data[ 'secret_refs'][0]['secret_ref'] = secret_ref_1 create_container_defaults_data[ 'secret_refs'][1]['secret_ref'] = secret_ref_2 create_container_defaults_data[ 'secret_refs'][2]['secret_ref'] = secret_ref_3 create_container_rsa_data[ 'secret_refs'][0]['secret_ref'] = secret_ref_1 create_container_rsa_data[ 'secret_refs'][1]['secret_ref'] = secret_ref_2 create_container_rsa_data[ 'secret_refs'][2]['secret_ref'] = secret_ref_3 self.secret_id_1 = secret_ref_1.split('/')[-1] self.secret_id_2 = secret_ref_2.split('/')[-1] self.secret_id_3 = secret_ref_3.split('/')[-1] def tearDown(self): self.secret_behaviors.delete_all_created_secrets() super(ContainersTestCase, self).tearDown() def _create_a_secret(self): secret_model = secret_models.SecretModel(**create_secret_defaults_data) resp, secret_ref = self.secret_behaviors.create_secret(secret_model) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 201) self.assertIsNotNone(secret_ref) return secret_ref def _get_a_secret(self, secret_id): resp = self.client.get('secrets/{0}'.format(secret_id)) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 200) return resp.json() # UNAUTHED # @testcase.attr('security') def test_unauthed_create_huge_dummy_token_no_proj_id(self): """Attempt to create a container with a dummy 3500-character token, and no project id Should return 401""" model = container_models.ContainerModel( **create_container_defaults_data ) headers = {'X-Auth-Token': 'a' * 3500} resp = self.client.post( 'containers', request_model=model, use_auth=False, extra_headers=headers ) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 401) @testcase.attr('security') def test_unauthed_create_no_proj_id(self): """Attempt to create a container without a token or project id Should return 401""" model = container_models.ContainerModel( **create_container_defaults_data ) resp = self.client.post( 'containers', request_model=model, use_auth=False ) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 401) @testcase.attr('security') def test_unauthed_get_no_proj_id(self): """Attempt to get a container without a token or project id Should return 401""" headers = { 'Accept': '*/*', 'Accept-Encoding': '*/*' } resp = self.client.get( dummy_container_ref, extra_headers=headers, use_auth=False ) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 401) @testcase.attr('security') def test_unauthed_delete_no_proj_id(self): """Attempt to delete a container without a token or project id Should return 401""" resp = self.client.delete(dummy_container_ref, use_auth=False) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 401) @testcase.attr('security') def test_unauthed_huge_dummy_token_with_proj_id(self): """Attempt to create a container with a dummy 3500-character token and a dummy project id Should return 401""" model = container_models.ContainerModel( **create_container_defaults_data ) headers = { 'X-Auth-Token': 'a' * 3500, 'X-Project-Id': dummy_project_id } resp = self.client.post( 'containers', request_model=model, use_auth=False, extra_headers=headers ) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 401) @testcase.attr('security') def test_unauthed_create_with_proj_id(self): """Attempt to create a container with a project id, but not a token Should return 401""" model = container_models.ContainerModel( **create_container_defaults_data ) headers = {'X-Project-Id': dummy_project_id} resp = self.client.post( 'containers', request_model=model, use_auth=False, extra_headers=headers ) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 401) @testcase.attr('security') def test_unauthed_get_with_proj_id(self): """Attempt to get a container with a project id, but not a token Should return 401""" headers = { 'Accept': '*/*', 'Accept-Encoding': '*/*', 'X-Project-Id': dummy_project_id } resp = self.client.get( dummy_container_ref, extra_headers=headers, use_auth=False ) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 401) @testcase.attr('security') def test_unauthed_delete_with_proj_id(self): """Attempt to delete a container with a project id, but not a token Should return 401""" headers = {'X-Project-Id': dummy_project_id} resp = self.client.delete( dummy_container_ref, use_auth=False, extra_headers=headers ) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 401)

added_lines: Hardware Inspection ------------------- Starting with Kilo release Ironic supports hardware inspection that simplifies enrolling nodes. Inspection allows Ironic to discover required node properties once required ``driver_info`` fields (e.g. IPMI credentials) are set by an operator. There are two kinds of inspection supported by Ironic: #. Out-of-band inspection supported by some vendor drivers. #. In-band inspection supported by generic drivers (``pxe_ipmitool``, ``pxe_ipminative``, ``pxe_ssh``) driven by ironic-discoverd_. As of Kilo release this feature needs to be explicitly enabled in the configuration by setting ``enabled = true`` in ``[discoverd]`` section. You may need to set ``service_url`` too if ironic-discoverd is installed on another node or is using non-standard port. .. _ironic-discoverd: https://github.com/stackforge/ironic-discoverd

commit_message:
Fix ComputeNode backport for Service.obj_make_compatible

The previous implementation was setting anyway the ComputeNode object version
to 1.10. It consequently breaks compatiblity with Juno compute nodes that can
only understand ComputeNode <1.6

Change-Id: Ib2b63d0fb482410233ee42b1ff1c697229c77958
Closes-Bug: #1431201

added_lines: @mock.patch.object(objects.ComputeNodeList, 'get_all_by_host') def test_obj_make_compatible_with_juno_computes(self, get_all_by_host): service_obj = objects.Service( context=self.context, **fake_service) service_obj.binary = 'nova-compute' fake_service_dict = fake_service.copy() fake_service_dict['binary'] = 'nova-compute' fake_compute_obj = objects.ComputeNode(host=fake_service['host']) get_all_by_host.return_value = [fake_compute_obj] # Juno version of Service object is 1.4 service_obj.obj_make_compatible(fake_service_dict, '1.4') self.assertEqual( '1.6', fake_service_dict['compute_node']['nova_object.version'])

commit_message:
Fix confusing log output in nova/nova/network/linux_net.py

When reloading dnsmasq, this log message
"Hupping dnsmasq threw ..." is a little difficult.

"kill -HUP dnsmasq threw ..." is better.

Change-Id: I3e163499186543490a89ddc8e86cec89fe8a712f
Closes-Bug: #1429755
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/69/162569/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: LOG.error(_LE('kill-HUPping dnsmasq threw %s'), exc)

commit_message:
Fix wrong log when reschedule is disabled

Whenever the reschedule is enabled, compute will print logs
Build of instance uuid was re-scheduled: reason
this will confusing people because actually they didn't
expect reschedule action. This patch moves the log after
'retry' check, so no 'retry' info will not print log.

Closes-Bug: #1431203
Change-Id: I1fd3e8450f9be054b621747cd4134445942f4505
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/24/164124/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: LOG.debug(e.format_message(), instance=instance)

commit_message:
Remove 'adding-new-users-to-devstack' doc on_devstack.rst

Since https://review.openstack.org/#/c/128509/
heat no longer requires the "heat_stack_owner"
role by default, as we now delegate all roles
via the trust. So remove the 'adding-new-users-to-devstack'
doc.

Change-Id: Ia84e72b7b0cb4a1a2f40fc8bd259f99fc495de82
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/36/155636/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: Adding new users to DevStack ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ When DevStack is configured and launched with ``stack.sh`` script, Heat creates a specific role in Keystone (``heat_stack_owner`` by default) and assigns this role to both default users created by DevStack (admin and demo). If you later create another user, and want this user to be able to use all capabilities of Heat, don't forget to assign the ``heat_stack_owner`` role to this user too, otherwise the new user will not be allowed to create stacks.

commit_message:
Rename experimental nova py27 to run on dsvm nodes

Change the name of the experimental-nova-python27 job to include
dsvm so that zuul will expect to find it registered on devstack
nodes.

commit_message:
Start using in-band inspection

Start using in-band inspection with ironic-discoverd, but do not
instantiate the driver interface when discoverd support is disabled in
the config file.

* Check the CONF option prior to instantiating DiscoverdInspect class
  and binding it to any driver interface
* Updates unit tests to better test the loading (or lack thereof) of the
  driver.inspect interface, based on the CONF option

If in-band discovery is enabled by setting [discoverd] enabled=True in
the config file, then the following drivers will bind it to their
inspect interface:
* pxe_ssh
* pxe_ipmitool
* pxe_ipminative
* pxe_drac

This patch also fixes a few nits (copied from previous reviews).

The bug tagged below presently affects only the "fake" driver. Without
the above-mentioned changes, enabling discoverd for any
production-facing driver would have led to the problem described there.

Updated UnsupportedDriverExtension error message to suggest that
the extension might be disabled.

Co-authored-by: Devananda van der Veen <devananda.vdv@gmail.com>

Closes-bug: #1431999
Implements: blueprint inband-properties-discovery
Change-Id: I1dd844525852b1ec806f286d01dfc95313c6ad94

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-16 01:21:00.000000000', 'files': ['swift/common/utils.py', 'test/unit/common/test_utils.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/99a3d1a1c5d9591eed5378cf83af78578b01b386', 'message': 'Fix the prefix of messages caputured from stderr

commit_message:
Fix the prefix of messages caputured from stderr

Swift caputures both sys.stdout and sys.stderr messages and
transfers them to syslog. However, whole of the messages
uses the "STDOUT:" prefix, currently.

It will be quite confusable for debugging purpose because we
cannot make sure whether "Swift didn't caputure stderr" or
"Swift captured stderr but didn't show it" when we want to log
some stderr messages.

This patch enables to allow a new prefix "STDERR:" and use it
for sys.stderr.

Change-Id: Idf4649e9860b77c3600a5cd0a3e0bd674b31fb4f

subject: Move pylint checks to pep8 testenv
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-02 17:26:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-vpnaas/commit/5c9a70c8c09afb3d95ac7f3b38d31f3e85f088c9', 'message': 'The tox.ini file has been updated such that the pylint violation checks
have been moved to the pep8 testenv. If pylint is executed as a separate

commit_message:
Move pylint checks to pep8 testenv

The tox.ini file has been updated such that the pylint violation checks
have been moved to the pep8 testenv. If pylint is executed as a separate
job, handling potential unexpected breakages would become a difficult job
because we need to get infra involved. Also, an extra node needs to be
spinned, when the checks can easily be handled by the node for the pep8
job.

Further, having pylint running with tox -epep8 would help developers
become aware of pylint violations sooner rather than later, if they forget
to run the pylint testenv too before submitting the change.

Change-Id: I9a6b981998fd04051895642adc16a961f6c6a766

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-27 23:01:57.000000000', 'files': ['tox.ini'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lbaas/commit/94d1a1e19425133be5346a32e3975da7ab746e13', 'message': 'Move pylint checks to pep8 testenv

from Neutron into Neutron-LBaaS project

This change proposes to move pylint violation checks to the pep8
testenv. This changes make pylint gating within Neutron as it would
participate in the vote.  Having pylint executed on a separate job makes
it difficult to handle potential unexpected breakages, because we need
to get infra involved. When we need to renable the job, it is equally
painful.

Furthermore, it also causes us to spin an extra node, when the checks
can easily be handled by the node for the pep8 job.

become aware of pylint violations sooner rather than later, if they
"forget" to run the pylint testenv too before submitting the change.

Change-Id: I814051122e2e71bc4e55ab283786651de722309f
'}]
commit_message:
Move pylint checks to pep8 testenv

Replicates Change-Id: Ida6ae44a837d1761f5ce3e8a92f8850407f5cd16
from Neutron into Neutron-LBaaS project

This change proposes to move pylint violation checks to the pep8
testenv. This changes make pylint gating within Neutron as it would
participate in the vote.  Having pylint executed on a separate job makes
it difficult to handle potential unexpected breakages, because we need
to get infra involved. When we need to renable the job, it is equally
painful.

Furthermore, it also causes us to spin an extra node, when the checks
can easily be handled by the node for the pep8 job.

Finally, having pylint running with tox -epep8 "helps" developers
become aware of pylint violations sooner rather than later, if they
"forget" to run the pylint testenv too before submitting the change.

Change-Id: I814051122e2e71bc4e55ab283786651de722309f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lbaas refs/changes/37/160037/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add a common HBase lib in hdfs on cluster start

HBase applications written in Java require JARs on the HBase classpath.
Java actions launched from Oozie may reference JARs stored in hdfs
using the `oozie.libpath` configuration value, but there is no
standard HBase directory location in hdfs that is installed with Oozie.
By adding checkbox in the create cluster and job execution page, sahara
provided an option to build the directory at cluster launch time, and also
provided the common hbase lib when executing hbase edp job.

partially implements bp: edp-add-hbase-lib

Change-Id: I9ebf26c1e914e9eb538499b02997960ac442900e

commit_message:
Extend images CLI v2 with new sorting syntax

This code enables new syntax for sorting output with multiple
keys and directions based on API Working group sorting
guidelines.

It's a client code to consume API modified in change
Ie4ccfefa0492a3ac94cc7e22201f2f2be5c1cdbb

Example:
glance --os-image-api-version 2 --sort name:desc,size:asc

Implements-blueprint: glance-sorting-enhancements
DocImpact
Depends-On: Ie4ccfefa0492a3ac94cc7e22201f2f2be5c1cdbb
Change-Id: I36a9fa9f0508fea1235de2ac3a0d6a093e1af635
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-glanceclient refs/changes/81/148981/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_do_image_list_new_sorting_syntax(self): input = { 'page_size': 18, 'visibility': True, 'member_status': 'Fake', 'owner': 'test', 'checksum': 'fake_checksum', 'tag': 'fake tag', 'properties': [], 'sort': 'name:desc,size:asc', 'sort_key': [], 'sort_dir': [] } args = self._make_args(input) with mock.patch.object(self.gc.images, 'list') as mocked_list: mocked_list.return_value = {} test_shell.do_image_list(self.gc, args) exp_img_filters = { 'owner': 'test', 'member_status': 'Fake', 'visibility': True, 'checksum': 'fake_checksum', 'tag': 'fake tag' } mocked_list.assert_called_once_with( page_size=18, sort='name:desc,size:asc', filters=exp_img_filters) utils.print_list.assert_called_once_with({}, ['ID', 'Name'])

subject: Add the ability to specify the sort dir for each key
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-01-20 18:57:01.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-glanceclient/commit/21df7955c87f48ddbdbcdad9cb29c4ffc6c308b1', 'message': 'Add the ability to specify the sort dir for each key

Adds client code to consume API modified in change #148326
Extends cli for v2 with multiple sort dirs
Example:
glance --os-image-api-version 2 image-list \

commit_message:
Add the ability to specify the sort dir for each key

Adds client code to consume API modified in change
Ib43b53abfba7cb5789d916a014376cf38fc5245b

Extends CLI for v2 with multiple sort dirs
Example:
glance --os-image-api-version 2 image-list \
--sort-key name --sort-dir asc --sort-key size --sort-dir desc

Implements-blueprint: glance-sorting-enhancements
DocImpact
Depends-On: Ib43b53abfba7cb5789d916a014376cf38fc5245b
Change-Id: Ia20716f3c75299f796879299da317b2e81496088

commit_message:
Adds the ability to sort images with multiple keys

Adds client code to consume API modified in change
Ib7a6aeb2df3bc5d23fe8e070290b5bfcab00c0f5

Extends CLI for v2 with multiple sort keys
Example:

commit_message:
Standardized Secret Encoding

Defined the different types a secret can be as well as the encoding
for the secret. A secret can now be one of symmetric, public, private,
certificate, passphrase, or opaque. Each secret type now a specific
encoding that is defined.

The Secrets REST API has been updated to allow a secret type to be
specified when storing a secret.

store_crypto is now storing public and private keys in Distinguished
Encoding Rules (DER) format using the simple_crypto plugin. This makes
it consistant with the rest of the keys that are stored in binary
format. It also makes the store_crypto get_secret call easier because
it can assume that it needs to base64 encode everything before
returning it to the caller.

All secrets returned from the secret stores are to be base64 encoded.
Updated the translations module to account for this.

Co-authored-by: Kaitlin Farr <kaitlin.farr@jhuapl.edu>
Change-Id: I5e91c16d0031b3b4791e9dcee4aa48fcc821cf66
Implements: blueprint content-types

subject: Fix ContainerBroker to use policy-0 in default
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-23 09:21:07.000000000', 'files': ['test/unit/container/test_backend.py', 'swift/container/backend.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/16b435a4a8ae12f456a55872fd8ebe21b0841704', 'message': 'Fix ContainerBroker to use policy-0 in default

Fix ContainerBroker to initialize as policy-0 on policy_stat
table in default when storage_policy_index argument is NOT given.

Current ContainerBroker makes policy-1 stats in default because
the "None" value will be passed through to the last function of
db access query (i.e. a query like as "INSERT INTO policy_stat
(storage_policy_index) VALUES (None)" will appear) which results
in a row "(1, 0, 0)" (the first value is the policy index) by
the PRIMARY KEY constraint on sqlite.

In worst case, container db keeps two policies, and then, ContainerBroker.get_info
might return invalid (non-touched) policy_stat information as container information.
(See tests in detail)

When using ContainerBroker with no storage_policy_index argument,
it should always act policy-0 simply.

Note that this patch doesn't affect immediately Swift behavior because
current swift ensures to use policy-0 on "Container-Server" when invalid
policy (includes None) is given. However, we should recheck also in
ContainerBroker for safety to prevent the unfortunate behavior above.

Change-Id: If64f0c94c069a2cc3140c99f21b8d371c183e28a
'}]
commit_message:
Fix ContainerBroker to use policy-0 in default

Fix ContainerBroker to initialize as policy-0 on policy_stat
table in default when storage_policy_index argument is NOT given.

Current ContainerBroker makes policy-1 stats in default because
the "None" value will be passed through to the last function of
db access query (i.e. a query like as "INSERT INTO policy_stat
(storage_policy_index) VALUES (None)" will appear) which results
in a row "(1, 0, 0)" (the first value is the policy index) by
the PRIMARY KEY constraint on sqlite.

In worst case, container db keeps two policies, and then, ContainerBroker.get_info
might return invalid (non-touched) policy_stat information as container information.
(See tests in detail)

When using ContainerBroker with no storage_policy_index argument,
it should always act policy-0 simply.

Note that this patch doesn't affect immediately Swift behavior because
current swift ensures to use policy-0 on "Container-Server" when invalid
policy (includes None) is given. However, we should recheck also in
ContainerBroker for safety to prevent the unfortunate behavior above.

Change-Id: If64f0c94c069a2cc3140c99f21b8d371c183e28a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/19/158219/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if storage_policy_index is None: storage_policy_index = 0

commit_message:
Launch Instance Step - Select Flavor

This is one step in launch instance wizard work flow.

This commit adds a basic select flavor table.
Additional commits will follow to add a details row for
each flavor.

Co-Authored-By: Tyr Johanson <tyr@hp.com>
Partially Implements: blueprint launch-instance-redesign
Change-Id: Ideda45897581f2ee51df6dc4ca78487abaeb4452
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/45/158945/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Launch Instance Model

'}, {'number': 68, 'created': '2015-03-12 03:29:59.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/1dd7eab6cc2aec1570e0177f5723148f48bf5b59', 'message': 'WIP - Launch Instance Model

This is the M part in MVC for launch instance that will use the APIs
to load data and send request to server via the APIs.

This model is injected into to LaunchInstanceCtrl and available to all
controllers for every step in the work flow.

To access:
 - Add to local_setting.py:
     LAUNCH_INSTANCE_NG_ENABLED = True
 - Then go to:
     http://localhost:9000/project/instances/
 - Then click the left "Launch Instance" button.

To disable the legacy launch instance button:
 - Add to local_setting.py:
    LAUNCH_INSTANCE_LEGACY_ENABLED = True

Partially Implements: blueprint launch-instance-redesign
Co-Authored-By: Travis Tripp <travis.tripp@hp.com>
Co-Authored-By: Neill Cox <neill.cox@ingenious.com.au>
Co-Authored-By: Richard Jones <r1chardj0n3s@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I040f13f7d1fd336fcd1070bdbe0c81bd5a828d43

commit_message:
Launch Instance Model

This is the M part in MVC for launch instance that will use the APIs
to load data and send request to server via the APIs.

This model is injected into to LaunchInstanceCtrl and available to all
controllers for every step in the work flow.

To access:
 - Add to local_setting.py:
     LAUNCH_INSTANCE_NG_ENABLED = True
 - Then go to:
     http://localhost:9000/project/instances/
 - Then click the left "Launch Instance" button.

To disable the legacy launch instance button:
 - Add to local_setting.py:
    LAUNCH_INSTANCE_LEGACY_ENABLED = True

Partially Implements: blueprint launch-instance-redesign
Co-Authored-By: Travis Tripp <travis.tripp@hp.com>
Co-Authored-By: Neill Cox <neill.cox@ingenious.com.au>
Co-Authored-By: Richard Jones <r1chardj0n3s@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Tyr Johanson <tyr@hp.com>
Co-Authored-By: Matt Borland <matt.borland@hp.com>
Change-Id: I040f13f7d1fd336fcd1070bdbe0c81bd5a828d43

commit_message:
Adding Advanced step to base launch instance wizard

A new step named `Advanced' is needed in Launch instance wizard.
This patch adds placeholder files for it.

Partially Implements: blueprint launch-instance-redesign
Change-Id: I142201cc76ae933d46b21899418f4b8912478c67

commit_message:
Demo - Launch instance wizard

This is a demo patch for launch instance wizard.
After loading Horizon UI, you will see a blue button
on the top-left corner of the screen, a launch instance
wizard can be opened by clicking on the button.

The launch instance wizard only has basic form for each
step in the launch instance work flow at this moment.

Change-Id: If28213b045b58a4356380d08aac3874daba95348

commit_message:
Complete docker compose setup.

This change proposes a minimal openstack deployment stood up using
docker-compose.  Included is a script to generate the necessary
environment variables for use by the containers as well as an
'openrc'.  There is also a script which demonstrates starting the
included services.

We have this working locally using patched containers and can start
instances with networking etc.  However, there are several changes
required to various containers that will need to be made to get this
working.  We are also using Steven Dake's patches to docker-compose to
allow the use of pid=host.  I propose we either merge this change or
build changes on top of this to get a functioning installation.

Co-authored-by: Ryan Hallisey <rhallise@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I5e6051054d31edf9840c3a22502d4a7963893f29

subject: Add process guards + invalidate to the connection pool
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-16 16:30:08.000000000', 'files': ['oslo_db/tests/sqlalchemy/test_sqlalchemy.py', 'oslo_db/sqlalchemy/session.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.db/commit/3e6a30c396aa42ef0eccb5b3625af728d8d3f437', 'message': "Add process guards + invalidate to the connection pool

It's not safe for a database TCP connection to be
shared to a child process, as this is a file descriptor
which will maintain its state on both sides.  Applications
such as Cinder which spin up multiprocessing subprocesses
at startup time are subject to race conditions as a result.

Instead of requiring that engines be explicitly prepared
within a child process, we can detect and accommodate
this situation in the connection pool itself, by tracking
the originating pid of a connection, and if it changes
on checkout, by invalidating.

Change-Id: If116f7b7140b3eba064d8147e5f637a05beb1cd8
(cherry picked from commit ebbf23d6490159f0c8f4f35a08fb4b80371cd080)
"}]
commit_message:
Add process guards + invalidate to the connection pool

It's not safe for a database TCP connection to be
shared to a child process, as this is a file descriptor
which will maintain its state on both sides.  Applications
such as Cinder which spin up multiprocessing subprocesses
at startup time are subject to race conditions as a result.

Instead of requiring that engines be explicitly prepared
within a child process, we can detect and accommodate
this situation in the connection pool itself, by tracking
the originating pid of a connection, and if it changes
on checkout, by invalidating.

Change-Id: If116f7b7140b3eba064d8147e5f637a05beb1cd8
(cherry picked from commit ebbf23d6490159f0c8f4f35a08fb4b80371cd080)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.db refs/changes/67/164767/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import osfrom sqlalchemy import exc _add_process_guards(engine) def _add_process_guards(engine): """Add multiprocessing guards. Forces a connection to be reconnected if it is detected as having been shared to a sub-process. """ @sqlalchemy.event.listens_for(engine, "connect") def connect(dbapi_connection, connection_record): connection_record.info['pid'] = os.getpid() @sqlalchemy.event.listens_for(engine, "checkout") def checkout(dbapi_connection, connection_record, connection_proxy): pid = os.getpid() if connection_record.info['pid'] != pid: LOG.debug(_LW( "Parent process %(orig)s forked (%(newproc)s) with an open " "database connection, " "which is being discarded and recreated."), {"newproc": pid, "orig": connection_record.info['pid']}) connection_record.connection = connection_proxy.connection = None raise exc.DisconnectionError( "Connection record belongs to pid %s, " "attempting to check out in pid %s" % (connection_record.info['pid'], pid) )

commit_message:
Fix upload built artifact in gerrit job

This job was Erorring with message..

  cp: cannot stat ‘gerrit/buck-out/gen/release.war’:
      No such file or directory

It is because there was a 'cd gerrit' step before doing this copy
so it's already in the 'gerrit' directory.

Change-Id: Iec5ab6d6f53ed5049227c1a5b478e60de5721036

commit_message:
add the package 'which' to fedora

in fedora minimal installations, the package "which"
is not included, but required for run_tests.sh to install
necessary dependencies

Change-Id: I31b43de1f0f72be2d8d3d97af2909744080ad706

commit_message:
Adding Security Checklist

Adding seperate section for checklists. This is an initial
commit to get feedback on the format. Starting with checklist
on Keystone (identity).

Change-Id: If36e99aae03f35775e9df665f7a204580717f5a2
Partial-Bug: #1342993
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/security-doc refs/changes/64/157164/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <section xmlns="http://docbook.org/ns/docbook" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" version="5.0" xml:id="identity-checklist"> <?dbhtml stop-chunking?> <title>Checklist</title> <section xml:id="ownership-of-conf-files"> <title>Is user/group ownership for /etc/keystone/keystone. conf set to keystone?</title> <para>Configuration files contain critical parameters and information required for smooth functioning of the component. If an unprivileged user, either intentionally or accidently modifies or deletes any of the parameters or the file itself then it would cause severe availability issue causing denial of service to the other end users. Thus user and group ownership for such critical configuration files must be set to that component owner.</para> <para>Run the following command:</para> <screen><prompt>$</prompt> <userinput>stat -L -c "%U %G" /etc/keystone/keystone.conf | egrep "keystone keystone"</userinput></screen> <para>Pass: If user/group ownership for /etc/keystone/ keystone.conf is set to keystone. The above command shows output keystone keystone. </para> <para>Fail: If otherwise.</para> </section> <section xml:id="permissions-on-conf-files"> <title>Are strict permissions set for Keystone configuration files?</title> <para>As listed in the previous check, configuration files contain critical information, it is recommended to set strict access permissions for such configuration files. </para> <para>Run the following command:</para> <screen><prompt>$</prompt> <userinput>stat -L -c "%a" /etc/keystone/keystone.conf</userinput></screen> <para>Pass: If permissions are set to 640 or stricter. </para> <para>Fail: If otherwise.</para> </section> <section xml:id="max_request_body"> <title>Is value of parameter max_request_body_size set to default(114688)?</title> <para>The parameter max_request_body_size defines the maximum body size per request in bytes. If the maximum size is not defined, the attacker could craft an arbitary request of large size causing the service to crash and finally resulting in Denial Of Service attack. Assigning the maximum value ensures that any malicious oversized request gets blocked ensuring continued availability of the component.</para> <para>Pass: If value of parameter max_request_body_size in /etc/keystone/keystone.conf is set to default (114688) </para> <para>Fail: If value of parameter max_request_body_size is not set.</para> </section> </section>

commit_message:
Prevent for miltiple autocreate base interface for subinterfaces.

Fix generate_network_config function
 * Prevent from multiple base interface autocreation for subinterface.
 * Change order when transformation for base interface comes after
   transformation for subinterface.

Fuel-CI: disable
Closes-bug: #1430693
Change-Id: I5c785209131ec45809ce18afa28f6b2c19c4d34d

We should merge properties from this to autocreated early # transformation and forget this. # # It's looks like some strange reordering tmp[i].merge! t debug("Auto-add 'move-properties-for-port(#{t[:name]})', because one autocreated early.") else tmp << t

commit_message:
made all status values translatable in port table

in port table, all the value of the status column
are not translatable, since some of the status
values are missing in the display choice tuple.

this patch adding the missing port status values
in the display choice tuple.

Change-Id: I44755a86205df8b561e3c0b48a299e08e6ae6986
Closes-Bug: #1432505

commit_message:
REVERT: Centos workaround "Flush routes after interface up."

due:
* this implementation break deployment process on Centos
* L3-aware properties should be changed inside L3-level resources

Fuel-CI: disable
Blueprint: refactor-l23-linux-bridges
Change-Id: I02c64d255b8bb856ecfbf42349b2fad0486f4183

commit_message:
Fixed nosec flagging

nosec flags are now detected at the end of any line (even within multi-line
statements), and that line only is skipped (no tests are run).
The nosec flag is detected in a comment at the end of a line, and the check
is both case insensitive, and ignores whitespace.
As this fix is in the testing logic, rather than the reporting logic, nosec
will be honoured for all reporting mediums.

Change-Id: I95940ea06827a567eb2acae7071914f6f535fe10
Closes-Bug: #1432012

Change-Id: I0b5ab727fba526724e44894bb7b84855e3ec0351
Implements: blueprint mdns-designate-mdns-tsig
'}]
commit_message:
Implement TSIG Support in mDNS

Implements support for scoped TSIG Keys in MiniDNS. When a non-tsig
signed request is received, we assume the default pool should be
used.

Change-Id: I0b5ab727fba526724e44894bb7b84855e3ec0351
Implements: blueprint mdns-designate-mdns-tsig

commit_message:
Make heat auth_encryption_key random

Currently we have a hard-coded default for auth_encryption_key,
which isn't ideal as it's used as a salt for the DB encryption.

Instead, reference an OS::Heat::RandomString resource so we create
a random key for each deployment.

Change-Id: Ic76b89db17603c114d98d28c01f75cc287fb2e90

commit_message:
Remove merge.py from TripleO Heat Templates

Our Heat templates are currently put together using the `merge.py` script, which
helps us deal with duplication and provides fine-grained scaling support.

It was a temporary solution until Heat grew the features we needed. This spec
covers the rationale and steps towards converting our template to native Heat
functionality and removing `merge.py`.

Partial-Blueprint: tripleo-juno-remove-mergepy
Change-Id: I4b1ba84737325595b64c0e2168a652333e6fd352
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-specs refs/changes/39/97939/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================= Moving TripleO Heat Templates towards native Heat ================================================= ``merge.py`` is where we've accumulated the technical debt for our Heat templates [0]_. Apart from joining template snippets together, it added a host of other features, some of which never materialised. This spec describes the steps towards reducing the scope ``merge.py`` with the goal of removing it completely. We will use native Heat features where we can and document the rest, possibly driving new additions to the Heat template format. It is largely based on the April 2014 discussion in openstack-dev [1]_. Problem Description =================== Because of the mostly undocumented nature of ``merge.py`` our templates are difficult to understand or modify by newcomers (even those already familiar with Heat). With every feature we add to ``merge.py``, we're diverging from Heat, making it harder to go back. It adds additional complexity for anyone who wants to use our templates. While it is just one line in devtest, it is one more step that can fail and needs to be verified. ``merge.py`` has always been considered a short-term measure. Proposed Change =============== We can mostly do small changes that will let us to move forward incrementally. One painful merge is behind us (moving to software config), but converting to HOT syntax [2]_ will be another change with a large impact and a host of unpleasant rebasing. It's possible that we'll run into foreseen or unforeseen limitations that would prevent us from doing the switch while keeping all the current functionality. These can be treated as bugs / missing features in Heat (chances are, we won't be the only ones with these issues) and we should work with Heat developers to get them resolved. What follows is a roughly-ordered list of changes that ought to happen before we can drop ``merge.py``. The aim is to get rid of it completely, but we may encounter blockers preventing us from doing that. 1. Remove the custom resource types ----------------------------------- TripleO Heat templates and ``merge.py`` carry two custom types that serve no useful purpose: * OpenStack::ImageBuilder::Elements * OpenStack::Role These will be removed from the templates and corresponding code dropped from ``merge.py``. 2. Remove combining whitelisted resource types ---------------------------------------------- If we have two ``AWS::AutoScaling::LaunchConfiguration`` resources with the same name, ``merge.py`` will combine their ``Properties`` and ``Metadata``. This is not necessary in the software-config world. All custom merging logic will be removed -- running ``merge.py`` on files which contain an identically named resource will be an error. 3. Remove FileInclude --------------------- The goal of ``FileInclude`` was to keep individual Roles (to borrow a loaded term from TripleO UI) viable as templates that can be launched standalone. The canonical example is ``overcloud-nova-instance.yaml`` [3]_. This is precisely what *Provider Resources* and *Environments* [4]_ are designed to do. This step task will handle the removal of ``FileInclude`` from the templates and ``merge.py``. Alternatively (if we deem the temporary loss of a standalone compute instance role unbearable), we can split the pieces in common and update the ``Makefile`` to merge put them together. 4. Port TripleO Heat templates to HOT ------------------------------------- With most of non-Heat syntax out of the way, porting our CFN/YAML templates to pure HOT format [2]_ should be straightforward, if tedious. This will give us access to any current and future template features supported by Heat. 5. Move to Provider resources ----------------------------- Heat allows passing-in multiple templates when deploying a stack. These templates can map to custom resource types. Each template would represent a standalone role (compute server, controller, block storage, etc.) and it's ``Parameters`` and ``Outputs`` would map to the custom resource's ``properties`` and ``attributes``. Here's a hypothetical outline of ``compute.yaml``:: Parameters: flavor: type: string image: type: string amqp_host: type: string nova_compute_driver: type: string Resources: compute_instance: type: OS::Nova::Server properties: flavor: {get_param: flavor} image: {get_param: image} compute_deployment: type: OS::Heat::StructuredDeployment properties: server: {ref: compute_instance} config: {ref: compute_config} input_values: amqp_host: {get_param: amqp_host} nova_compute_driver: {get_param: nova_compute_driver} compute_config: type: OS::Heat::StructuredConfig properties: group: os-apply-config config: amqp: host: {get_input: amqp_host} nova: compute_driver: {get_input: nova_compute_driver} ... And similarly for ``controller.yaml``, ``block-storage.yaml`` and whatever else. The ``overcloud.yaml`` template would then look something like this:: Parameters: compute_flavor: type: string compute_image: type: string compute_amqp_host: type: string compute_driver: type: string ... Resources: compute0: type: OS::TripleO::Compute # defined in compute.yaml parameters: flavor: {get_param: compute_flavor} image: {get_param: compute_image} amqp_host: {get_param: compute_amqp_host} nova_compute_driver: {get_param: compute_driver} controller0: type: OS::TripleO::Controller # defined in controller.yaml parameters: flavor: {get_param: controller_flavor} image: {get_param: controller_image} ... Outputs: ... and so on. The mapping of a role to a type is specified in ``environment.yaml`` which is passed to ``heat stack-create`` along with all the templates:: resource_registry: OS::TripleO::Compute: file:///path/to/tripleo-heat-templates/compute.yaml OS::TripleO::Controller: file:///path/to/tripleo-heat-templates/controller.yaml OS::TripleO::BlockStorage: file:///path/to/tripleo-heat-templates/block-storage.yaml (we can also use this to store common parameters instead of having to pass them directly to Heat on ``stack-create``.) 6. Move to Heat-native scaling ------------------------------ Scaling of resources is currently handled by ``merge.py``. The ``--scale`` command line argument takes a resource name and duplicates it as needed (it's a bit more complicated than that, but that's beside the point). Heat has a native scaling ``OS::Heat::ResourceGroup`` [5]_ resource that does essentially the same thing:: scaled_compute: type: OS::Heat::ResourceGroup properties: count: 42 resource_def: type: OS::TripleO::Compute parameters: flavor: baremetal image: compute-image-rhel7 ... This will create 42 instances of compute hosts. There are two limitations prevented us from using this in the past. First, there is no way to specify metadata unique to each server. We want to be able to set different database usernames/passwords and propagate these where necessary. This should be solvable with software deployments and ``OS::Heat::RandomString`` [6]_. Second, we want to be able to specify which server to kill when scaling down. .. note:: (shadower) I'm fairly sure there's a blueprint for this already, but I can't find it. Regardless, the Heat developers are aware of this limitation (we're not the only ones that want it) and either they implement it (pester *radix* in ``#heat``) or they won't be against us doing so. 7. Replace Merge::Map with equivalent HOT functionality ------------------------------------------------------- We are using the custom ``Merge::Map`` helper function for returning a list of hostnames in various templates. This is pending on having a similar functionality (or similar) implemented in Heat. We need to raise a blueprint and possibly send out patches. Clint Byrum has sent a proposal to openstack-dev [7]_. The general attitude from the Heat developers towards Clint's proposal seem to be positive, but it's not high on their list. Alternatives ------------ This proposal is very t-h-t and Heat specific. One alternative is to do nothing and keep using and evolving ``merge.py``. That was never the intent, and most members of the core team do not consider this a viable long-term option. Security Impact --------------- This proposal does not affect the overall functionality of TripleO in any way. It just changes the way TripleO Heat templates are stored and written. If anything, this will move us towards more standard and thus more easily auditable templates. Other End User Impact --------------------- There should be no impact for the users of vanilla TripleO. More advanced users may want to customise the existing Heat templates or write their own. That will be made easier when we rely on standard Heat features only. Performance Impact ------------------ This moves some of the template-assembling burden from ``merge.py`` to Heat. It will likely also end up producing more resources and nested stacks on the background. That could in theory affect the performance of Heat engine, but: 1. it is likely going to be negligible 2. if it's not, that's a bug in Heat Other Deployer Impact --------------------- Again, the deployment should remain exactly the same. How we structure our templates his is an implementation detail. Developer Impact ---------------- This should not affect non-Heat and non-TripleO OpenStack developers. There will likely be a slight learning curve for the TripleO developers who want to write and understand our Heat templates. Chances are, we will also encounter bugs or unforeseen complications while swapping ``merge.py`` for Heat features. The impact on Heat developers would involve processing the bugs and feature requests we uncover. This will hopefully not be an avalanche. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Tomas Sedovic <lp: tsedovic> <irc: shadower> Work Items ---------- 1. Remove the custom resource types 2. Remove combining whitelisted resource types 3. Remove FileInclude 4. Port TripleO Heat templates to HOT 5. Move to Provider resources 6. Move to Heat-native scaling 7. Replace Merge::Map with equivalent HOT functionality Dependencies ============ * A modern Heat with ResourceGroup, HOT support and provider resources (Havana/Icehouse should be fine) * Heat support for choosing the victim on scale-down * Heat support for Merge::Map-equivalent functionality Testing ======= All of these changes will be made to the tripleo-heat-templates repository and should be testable by our CI just as any other t-h-t change. Documentation Impact ==================== We don't have any official documentation for the current state of affairs, so none. We will want to document the post-merge.py situation and provide guides on writing new roles and so on. References ========== .. [0] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates .. [1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-April/031915.HTML .. [2] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/heat/template_guide/hot_guide.html .. [3] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/nova-compute-instance.yaml .. [4] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/heat/template_guide/environment.html .. [5] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/heat/template_guide/openstack.html#OS::Heat::ResourceGroup .. [6] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/heat/template_guide/openstack.html#OS::Heat::RandomString .. [7] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-February/027536.html

commit_message:
Clean up race condition in functional tests

This could all be made much fancier - but in general, for now, kill
concurrency until we can get much richer isolation put in - and make
sure that we're only cleaning up servers that we created in the test.

Change-Id: Iea341076f55f41573ee2bb0f378c8602d21b39a2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/shade refs/changes/61/164761/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: commands = python setup.py testr --slowest --testr-args='--concurrency=1 {posargs}'

commit_message:
Cache agent parameters for later invocations

When parameters are passed to agent through virtual
media, the device might be connected only for a short
while (dur to swift temp-url expiration, ironic removing
the floppy image, etc).  This change will enable agent
to cache the parameters and use it for any time later on.
After caching, the agent parameters need not be re-read
from /proc/cmdline or from the virtual media device.

Implements: blueprint ipa-as-default-ramdisk
Change-Id: Ia8c7020c91c987ec884c5640421f0583dbf1c3d9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-python-agent refs/changes/96/164596/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import copy# Agent parameters can be pased by kernel command-line arguments and/or # by virtual media. Virtual media parameters passed would be available # when the agent is started, but might not be available for re-reading # later on because: # * Virtual media might be exposed from Swift and swift temp url might # expire. # * Ironic might have removed the floppy image from Swift after starting # the deploy. # # Even if it's available, there is no need to re-read from the device and # /proc/cmdline again, because it is never going to change. So we cache the # agent parameters that was passed (by proc/cmdline and/or virtual media) # when we read it for the first time, and then use this cache. AGENT_PARAMS_CACHED = dict() global AGENT_PARAMS_CACHED if AGENT_PARAMS_CACHED: params = copy.deepcopy(AGENT_PARAMS_CACHED) else: params = _read_params_from_file('/proc/cmdline') # If the node booted over virtual media, the parameters are passed # in a text file within the virtual media floppy. if params.get('boot_method', None) == 'vmedia': # Check if we have the parameters cached vmedia_params = _get_vmedia_params() params.update(vmedia_params) # Cache the parameters so that it can be used later on. AGENT_PARAMS_CACHED = copy.deepcopy(params)
deleted_lines: params = _read_params_from_file('/proc/cmdline') # If the node booted over virtual media, the parameters are passed # in a text file within the virtual media floppy. if params.get('boot_method', None) == 'vmedia': vmedia_params = _get_vmedia_params() params.update(vmedia_params)

commit_message:
Added new repository classes and controller classes for CAs

Adds repository and controller classes for the CAs, as well
as test for the repository and controller classes.

Implements: blueprint identify-cas
Change-Id: I0d03fab725bd799e20f40c99e5dd57ead07d8c48
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/81/147981/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2014 Red Hat, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import urllib import pecan from barbican.api import controllers from barbican.common import hrefs from barbican.common import utils from barbican import i18n as u from barbican.model import models from barbican.model import repositories as repo LOG = utils.getLogger(__name__) def _certificate_authority_not_found(): """Throw exception indicating certificate authority not found.""" pecan.abort(404, u._('Not Found. CA not found.')) def _requested_preferred_ca_not_a_project_ca(): """Throw exception indicating that preferred CA is not a project CA.""" pecan.abort( 400, u._('Cannot set CA as a preferred CA as it is not a project CA.') ) class CertificateAuthorityController(object): """Handles certificate authority retrieval requests.""" def __init__(self, ca_id, ca_repo=None, project_ca_repo=None, preferred_ca_repo=None): LOG.debug('=== Creating CertificateAuthorityController ===') self.ca_id = ca_id self.ca_repo = ca_repo or repo.CertificateAuthorityRepo() self.project_ca_repo = (project_ca_repo or repo.ProjectCertificateAuthorityRepo()) self.preferred_ca_repo = (preferred_ca_repo or repo.PreferredCertificateAuthorityRepo()) def __getattr__(self, name): route_table = { 'add-to-project': self.add_to_project, 'remove-from-project': self.remove_from_project, 'set-preferred': self.set_preferred, 'set-global-preferred': self.set_global_preferred, 'unset-global-preferred': self.unset_global_preferred, } if name in route_table: return route_table[name] raise AttributeError @pecan.expose(generic=True) @controllers.handle_exceptions(u._('Certificate Authority retrieval')) @controllers.enforce_rbac('certificate_authority:get') def index(self, external_project_id): LOG.debug("== Getting certificate authority for %s", self.ca_id) ca = self.ca_repo.get(entity_id=self.ca_id) if not ca: _certificate_authority_not_found() pecan.override_template('json', 'application/json') return ca @pecan.expose() @controllers.handle_exceptions(u._('CA Signing Cert retrieval')) @controllers.enforce_rbac('certificate_authority:get_cacert') def cacert(self, external_project_id): LOG.debug("== Getting signing cert for %s", self.ca_id) ca = self.ca_repo.get(entity_id=self.ca_id) if not ca: _certificate_authority_not_found() cacert = ca.ca_meta['ca_signing_certificate'].value pecan.override_template('json', 'application/json') return cacert @pecan.expose() @controllers.handle_exceptions(u._('CA Cert Chain retrieval')) @controllers.enforce_rbac('certificate_authority:get_ca_cert_chain') def intermediates(self, external_project_id): LOG.debug("== Getting CA Cert Chain for %s", self.ca_id) ca = self.ca_repo.get(entity_id=self.ca_id) if not ca: _certificate_authority_not_found() cert_chain = ca.ca_meta['intermediates'].value pecan.override_template('json', 'application/json') return cert_chain @pecan.expose() @controllers.handle_exceptions(u._('CA projects retrieval')) @controllers.enforce_rbac('certificate_authority:get_projects') def projects(self, external_project_id): LOG.debug("== Getting Projects for %s", self.ca_id) ca = self.ca_repo.get(entity_id=self.ca_id) if not ca: _certificate_authority_not_found() projects = ca.ca_projects if not projects: ca_projects_resp = {'projects': []} else: project_list = [] for p in projects: project_list.append(p.project_id) ca_projects_resp = {'projects': project_list} return ca_projects_resp @pecan.expose() @controllers.handle_exceptions(u._('Add CA to project')) @controllers.enforce_rbac('certificate_authority:add_to_project') def add_to_project(self, external_project_id): if pecan.request.method != 'POST': pecan.abort(405) LOG.debug("== Saving CA %s to project %s", self.ca_id, external_project_id) ca = self.ca_repo.get(entity_id=self.ca_id) if not ca: _certificate_authority_not_found() project_ca = models.ProjectCertificateAuthority(external_project_id, self.ca_id) self.project_ca_repo.create_from(project_ca) @pecan.expose() @controllers.handle_exceptions(u._('Remove CA from project')) @controllers.enforce_rbac('certificate_authority:remove_from_project') def remove_from_project(self, external_project_id): if pecan.request.method != 'POST': pecan.abort(405) LOG.debug("== Removing CA %s from project %s", self.ca_id, external_project_id) ca = self.ca_repo.get(entity_id=self.ca_id) if not ca: _certificate_authority_not_found() project_ca = self.project_ca_repo.get_by_create_date( project_id=external_project_id, ca_id=self.ca_id) if project_ca: self.project_ca_repo.delete_entity_by_id(project_ca.id, None) @pecan.expose() @controllers.handle_exceptions(u._('Set preferred project CA')) @controllers.enforce_rbac('certificate_authority:set_preferred') def set_preferred(self, external_project_id): if pecan.request.method != 'POST': pecan.abort(405) LOG.debug("== Setting preferred CA %s for project %s", self.ca_id, external_project_id) ca = self.ca_repo.get(entity_id=self.ca_id) if not ca: _certificate_authority_not_found() project_ca = self.project_ca_repo.get_by_create_date( project_id=external_project_id, ca_id=self.ca_id) if not project_ca: _requested_preferred_ca_not_a_project_ca() preferred_ca = self.preferred_ca_repo.get_project_entities( external_project_id) if preferred_ca: self.preferred_ca_repo.delete_entity_by_id(preferred_ca.id) preferred_ca = models.PreferredCertificateAuthority( external_project_id, self.id) self.preferred_ca_repo.create_from(preferred_ca) @pecan.expose() @controllers.handle_exceptions(u._('Set global preferred CA')) @controllers.enforce_rbac('certificate_authority:set_global_preferred') def set_global_preferred(self, external_project_id): if pecan.request.method != 'POST': pecan.abort(405) LOG.debug("== Set global preferred CA %s", self.ca_id) ca = self.ca_repo.get(entity_id=self.ca_id) if not ca: _certificate_authority_not_found() self._remove_global_preferred_ca() global_preferred_ca = models.PreferredCertificateAuthority( self.preferred_ca_repo.PREFERRED_PROJECT_ID, self.id) self.preferred_ca_repo.create_from(global_preferred_ca) @pecan.expose() @controllers.handle_exceptions(u._('Unset global preferred CA')) @controllers.enforce_rbac('certificate_authority:remove_from_project') def unset_global_preferred(self, external_project_id): if pecan.request.method != 'POST': pecan.abort(405) LOG.debug("== Unsetting global preferred CA") self._remove_global_preferred_ca() def _remove_global_preferred_ca(self): global_preferred_ca = self.preferred_ca_repo.get_project_entities( self.preferred_ca_repo.PREFERRED_PROJECT_ID) if global_preferred_ca: self.preferred_ca_repo.delete_entity_by_id(global_preferred_ca.id) class CertificateAuthoritiesController(object): """Handles certificate authority list requests.""" def __init__(self, ca_repo=None, project_ca_repo=None, preferred_ca_repo=None): LOG.debug('Creating CertificateAuthoritiesController') self.ca_repo = ca_repo or repo.CertificateAuthorityRepo() self.project_ca_repo = (project_ca_repo or repo.ProjectCertificateAuthorityRepo()) self.preferred_ca_repo = (preferred_ca_repo or repo.PreferredCertificateAuthorityRepo()) self.validator = None @pecan.expose() def _lookup(self, ca_id, *remainder): return CertificateAuthorityController( ca_id, self.ca_repo, self.project_ca_repo, self.preferred_ca_repo), remainder @pecan.expose(generic=True, template='json') @controllers.handle_exceptions(u._('Certificate Authorities retrieval')) @controllers.enforce_rbac('certificate_authorities:get') def index(self, external_project_id, **kw): LOG.debug('Start certificate_authorities on_get') plugin_name = kw.get('plugin_name', None) if plugin_name is not None: plugin_name = urllib.unquote_plus(plugin_name) plugin_ca_id = kw.get('plugin_ca_id', None) if plugin_ca_id is not None: plugin_ca_id = urllib.unquote_plus(plugin_ca_id) result = self.repo.get_by_create_date( offset_arg=kw.get('offset', 0), limit_arg=kw.get('limit', None), plugin_name=plugin_name, plugin_ca_id=plugin_ca_id, suppress_exception=True ) cas, offset, limit, total = result if not cas: cas_resp_overall = {'certificate_authorities': [], 'total': total} else: cas_resp = [ hrefs.convert_certificate_authority_to_href(s.id) for s in cas ] cas_resp_overall = hrefs.add_nav_hrefs( 'certificate_authorities', offset, limit, total, {'certificate_authorities': cas_resp} ) cas_resp_overall.update({'total': total}) return cas_resp_overall

commit_message:
Add additional checks for attributes

Some decorators (like dtt) do have a func attribute
but no "attr" and "value" attribute defined.
This leads to errors during pep8 gate check (see [1]).

[1]: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/153234/4

Closes-Bug: #1431267
Change-Id: Id16bce40e30ecb6bc5bff9b55650acc538ece3a9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/47/164647/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Error trying to delete snapshots on Hitachi driver
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-05 18:57:44.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/238794191317358185c85a3068818c8b4a0f70ff', 'message': 'Error trying to delete snapshots on Hitachi driver

Patch #133566 partially changed Volumes and Volume Snapshots to objects. This
change broke HBSD driver. The intended fix was to update driver to use the new
objects, but at this moment, "snapshot" object type received from manager
differs in "create_snapshot" and "create_volume_from_snapshot" methods, so the
new objects cannot be used across the driver. This is a temporary fix to keep
Driver and CI running. A subsequent patch is mentioned in #133566 that will
update the remaining parameters sent from API, and then the HBSD driver will
be updated as well.

Change-Id: I38edc3b8a924f16ec3cef848cffef5e1b48fef14
Closes-Bug: #1428609
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-03-06 22:49:33.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/6d6bcb4bfcaa56e4c8e2a9a838a1e3339e88db19', 'message': "Error trying to delete snapshots on Hitachi driver

Patch #133566 partially changed Volumes and Volume Snapshots to objects
and modified their attributes. This change broke HBSD driver, once the
'snapshot_metadata' attribute was replaced to 'metadata'.

Change-Id: I38edc3b8a924f16ec3cef848cffef5e1b48fef14
Closes-Bug: #1428609

Patch #133566 (Change-Id: I387018e80c8539565e99454db65d976030002c0f) partially

"}]
commit_message:
Error trying to delete snapshots on Hitachi driver

Patch #133566 (Change-Id: I387018e80c8539565e99454db65d976030002c0f) partially
changed Volumes and Volume Snapshots to objects and modified their attributes.
This change broke HBSD driver, once the 'snapshot_metadata' attribute was
replaced to 'metadata'.

Change-Id: I38edc3b8a924f16ec3cef848cffef5e1b48fef14
Closes-Bug: #1428609

commit_message:
Add Sentry service test in cdh plugin integration test

Currently we have no services test in the integration test
add sentry service test in cdh plugin

partially implements bp: add-service-test-in-integration

Change-Id: Idf658ba2f1022a43be64c6a506b5a8648e93c64c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara refs/changes/15/157915/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash -x set -e log=/tmp/config-test-log.txt case $1 in check_sentry) FUNC="check_sentry" ;; check_sentry_hive) FUNC="check_sentry_hive" ;; check_sentry_impala) FUNC="check_sentry_impala" ;; esac check_sentry(){ conffile_dir=$(sudo find / -name "*-sentry-SENTRY_SERVER" | head -1) if [ -z $conffile_dir ]; then echo "Sentry configuration file directory not found" >> $log exit 1 else conffile=$conffile_dir"/sentry-site.xml" fi conffile_tmp=/tmp/sentry-site.xml sudo cp $conffile $conffile_tmp sudo chmod 664 $conffile_tmp export HADOOP_CLASSPATH=:/usr/share/cmf/lib/postgresql-9.0-801.jdbc4.jar sentry --command schema-tool -conffile $conffile_tmp -dbType postgres -info if [ $? -eq 0 ]; then echo "Sentry schema-tool Successful" >> $log exit 0 else echo "Sentry schema-tool Fail" >> $log exit 1 fi } check_sentry_hive(){ echo "check hive with sentry check" } check_sentry_impala(){ echo "check impala with sentry check" } $FUNC

commit_message:
Raise exception if store location URL not found

Glance doesn't catch NotFound exception when --location parameter
is used with non-exist http store URL.

If the URL returns HTTP 404, glance is just ignoring it and returns
image-size as zero.

While getting the image-size caught NotFound exception as well
if location parameter is specified.

Depends-On: Ieb3dcb79ed9ba4368d0b3ca69b30095c1fd800b9
Change-Id: I9ffad7666c6e64c007c9938684903aed44e60151
Closes-Bug: 1316137

commit_message:
iscsi_ilo driver to support agent ramdisk

ilo.deploy.VendorPassthru now inherits from
agent_base_vendor.BaseAgentVendor and a new
continue_deploy method is added for enabling
iscsi deploy with agent ramdisk

Implements: blueprint ipa-as-default-ramdisk
Change-Id: I3783716cdb7fadc708fa8e17bb73168c430d6737

commit_message:
javelin: don't destroy floating IP resource

The code to destroy floating IP resources is broken today and needs more
work.
To bring back the CI again, let's drop this code and add a TODO so we
can work on it later once CI is back and we also have a new job testing
Grenade on Neutron.

Change-Id: I8cf7fb3aa7e361d603716afbd3cf98827151f094

elements: add Horizon

Install Horizon in elements:
* add package in pkg-map for the overcloud-controller
* install the package in the overcloud-controller

Sync the latest oslo incubated libraries and use oslo.log

This commit updates to the latest version of oslo incubated libraries for
stackforge/networking-odl. It also moves to use oslo.log.

New nova compute and nova network yml file for docker compose.

This one uses the single environment file and has a few changes
to mounted directories.

Spec for data version

Spec for data version intended to be part of the first
release of Kilo.

Change-Id: Ib1cf90ca78865090eb10b5f3a51c9240c9c0665f
Fixes: MNP-59
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-midonet refs/changes/82/162382/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/ =========== Data Import =========== In MidoNet 2.0, data stored in Neutron database can be imported to MidoNet Cluster, MidoNet's data storage service, on demand. Data import is useful for upgrades and fixing out-of-sync data in Cluster. This document describes the Neutron tool that provides the data import feature to the cloud operators. The Cluster design of data import is out of this document's scope. However, it is useful to know the high level overview of the Cluster design before reading the Neutron design explained in this document. Cluster treats each new import as a new generation of data. When an import occurs, it never overwrites the currently active data. By keeping all the past imports in its data storage, the rollback mechanism could be supported. It is up to the operator to instruct Cluster which import should be active. Cluster, when told that a different imported data set is activated, it signals to all the MidoNet agents to switch over to that data set. Uupgrade Process ---------------- Data import is most useful in the upgrade process. The upgrade process follows these steps: 1. Disable write API operations in Neutron, and wait until all the pending write operations are processed by Cluster 2. Signal to Cluster that data import is about to start, and start the import process 3. After the import completes, tell Cluster that the newly imported data set could be 'activated' so that the MidoNet agents could start migating over to the new data set 4. After verifying that everything is working, enable write API operations in Neutron After the step 3 above, if a rollback is necessary, the operator must instruct Cluster to go back to the previously active data set so that the MidoNet agents could also be notified to switch back. Problem Description =================== While MidoNet Cluster is designed to provide the data import feature, currently there is no tool made available in Neutron to facilitate it. Without such tool, the data import feature does not get exposed to the operators, making the upgrade process and data syncing between Neutron and MidoNet challenging. Additionally, because Cluster preserves all the imported data in the past, after some point, old data needs to be deleted to restore disk space. Currently, there is no tool to accomplish this, and the Cluster data could grow indefinitely. Proposed Change =============== midonet-db-manage, which manages the tasks table in Neutron DB among other DB related features, is enhanced with the following capabilities: * Toggle the write access of the tasks table between read-only and read-write modes * Through the tasks table, signal to Cluster that data import is about to start and execute the import * Maintain all the past import events and their summaries * Through the tasks table, signal Cluster to 'activate' a particular completed import * Tell Cluster to delete data created from a particular import for clean-up Tasks Write Access ------------------ The write access to the tasks table is set in the new column of the 'midonet_task_state' table. The default is read-write. The import operation is only allowed in the read-only mode, and the operator cannot switch back to read-write while the import is occurring. The plugin will throw 503 (Service Unavailable) on POST/PUT/DELETE API requests if the tasks table is in a read-only mode. Import Summary -------------- Each import event is summarized and saved in the 'midonet_imports' table. An import summary consists of globally unique id, time the import started and finished, and the number of tasks processed. If an import process was terminated before completion, 'finished_at' would remain unset, indicating an erroroneous state. Additionally, there is a column indicating which import is currently 'active' which is used in the data activation process explained in the 'Data Activation' section. Tasks Data Import ----------------- The import operation is implemented as follows: 1. midonet-db-manage truncates the tasks table and inserts a CREATE task of a new task type, IMPORT, in the first row. This task instructs Cluster that a new import has started, and it needs to prepare a new storage location to store the new data set. The 'resource_id' of the task is set to the import id. 2. Immediately following the CREATE IMPORT task insertion, midonet-db-manage queries Neutron DB and generates CREATE tasks for all the existing resources. Cluster processes them as usual and creates these resources in the backend. Data Activation --------------- An 'active' import means that the data originated from this import is what Cluster has instructed the MidoNet agents to use. When a particular import completes, the active flag does not get automatically updated to the completed import. midonet-db-manage offers a command to activate an import. When an import is activated, an IMPORT task is added to the tasks table to indicate to Cluster that it should instruct the agents to change to the specified imported data. This particular IMPORT task includes in its data the 'active' flag that is set to 'true'. The operational steps are the same in the case of a rollback, where the opearator simply activates one of the previous imports. To avoid potential operational error, only the successful imports ('finished_at' is set) could be activated. Import Deletion --------------- Deleting an import signals to Cluster to delete the data created from that import. Deletion is only allowed on inactive imports. A DELETE tasks of an IMPORT resource is added to the tasks table. REST API -------- None DB Model -------- **midonet_imports** +-------------------+---------+-----------------------------------------------+ | Name | Type | Description | +===================+=========+===============================================+ | id | Int | The primary key to indentify the import | +-------------------+---------+-----------------------------------------------+ | active | Bool | Indicates the active import | +-------------------+---------+-----------------------------------------------+ | started_at | DateTime| Time the import started | +-------------------+---------+-----------------------------------------------+ | finished_at | DateTime| Time the import finished | +-------------------+---------+-----------------------------------------------+ | task_count | Int | Number of tasks processed | +-------------------+---------+-----------------------------------------------+ At any point, only one import could be active. NULL 'finished_at' indicates that an import did not complete. **midonet_task_state** Add a new column to store the write access to the tasks table. +-------------------+---------+-----------------------------------------------+ | Name | Type | Description | +===================+=========+===============================================+ | readonly | Boolean | If true, tasks table is readonly | +-------------------+---------+-----------------------------------------------+ FLUSH task type is deleted, and a new resource type IMPORT is created so that multiple task operations (CREATE, UPDATE, DELETE) could be applied to one resource type. To start the import process, add this in row 1 of the tasks table: :: task_type: CREATE resource_type: IMPORT resource_id: <IMPORT_ID> data: {} To activate an import: :: task_type: UPDATE resource_type: IMPORT resource_id: <IMPORT_ID> data: {"activate": true} To delete an import: :: task_type: DELETE resource_type: IMPORT resource_id: <IMPORT_ID> data: {} Security -------- Similar to neutron-db-manage, only the admins are expected to run midonet-db-manage. While there is no special authentication mechanism implemented for this tool, the only way to run this script is if you have access to the management hosts in the cloud, and preventing unauthorized users from gaining such access is out of this document's scope. Client ------ The following command displays the information about the tasks state: :: midonet-db-manage task-state-show The following command sets the tasks table to readonly: :: midonet-db-manage task-readonly The following command sets the tasks table to readwrite: :: midonet-db-manage task-readwrite The following command displays all the past imports: :: midonet-db-manage import-list The following command triggers a new import: :: midonet-db-manage import-create The following command deletes an import: :: midonet-db-manage import-delete IMPORT_ID The following command activates an import (and deactivates the current active import): :: midonet-db-manage import-activate IMPORT_ID

commit_message:
Moving lineno into generic visitor

Currently each specific node visitor type that we implement adds
line number to the context.  Rather than do it separately in each
place we can just do it once in the generic node visitor.

Change-Id: I32cd96d2290a08ab603fa875466da8a8d6926950
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/bandit refs/changes/86/164786/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: self.context['lineno'] = node.lineno self.context['lineno'] = node.lineno self.context['lineno'] = node.lineno self.context['lineno'] = node.lineno self.context['lineno'] = node.lineno self.context['lineno'] = node.lineno self.context['lineno'] = node.lineno

commit_message:
Changing the log imports

Changing the log imports from
neutron.openstack.common import log to
oslo_log import log, due to change in latest neutron.

Change-Id: Ic7de94602feb088005f0b61e7d7963dde35a8ac0

deleted_lines: from neutron.openstack.common import log as logging

commit_message:
Improve hacking and remove useless unit tests

* Remove tests/unit/aas and test/unit/fixture
  fixtures are not used so just remove them
  aas - didn't have __init__.py files so these
  tests were not executed at all. By the way
  code related to this tests was removed earlier
  in this patch:
  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/152847/

* Remove all old py3 related hacking rules
  Now we have unit & functional jobs that checks them

* Add new hacking rule that protect us from usage of '

* Unified signature of all hacking methods
  (otherwise we are not able to make decorator)

* Add hacking rules decorator for skiping 3 types of lines:
  empty, commented, and with # noqa comment

Change-Id: I6bf2cc123325a4980edeb066a6c31aa685858f5b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/84/164384/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Mark the domain config API as experimental

This patch provides generic support for marking individual
JSON Home resources with a status, and uses that support to
mark the three APi variants for managing domain configs in the
database as 'experimental'.

Change-Id: Iae158f2943916fe78622b844c7e9837889e4cc2c
Implements: blueprint domain-config-ext

subject: Distinguish between luks and cryptsetup volume types
revisions:

TestEncryptedCinderVolumes was always creating the volume type in cinder
with a random name but 'luks' was always in the name since it's
hard-coded, which makes debugging failures in the cryptsetup test
difficult when you're looking at nova-compute logs.

Change the helper method to take a parameter for the volume type name

"}]
commit_message:
Distinguish between luks and cryptsetup volume types

TestEncryptedCinderVolumes was always creating the volume type in cinder
with a random name but 'luks' was always in the name since it's
hard-coded, which makes debugging failures in the cryptsetup test
difficult when you're looking at nova-compute logs.

Change the helper method to take a parameter for the volume type name
so we can distinguish between luks and cryptsetup.

Related-Bug: #1327218

Change-Id: If607ba6d389e6a482cfb1eb3af4fe895ed00f8db
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/59/164259/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
